{{Infobox islands | name = Yorks Islands | native_name = | sobriquet = | image_name = | image_size = | image_caption = | image_alt = | pushpin_map = USA Montana | pushpin_map_caption = | location = [[Missouri River]], [[Broadwater County, Montana]] | coordinates = {{coord|46|15|45|N|111|29|28|W|scale:25000|display=inline,title |name=Yorks Islands}}{{cite gnis |id=1853836 |name=Yorks Islands}} | total_islands = | major_islands = | area_sqmi = | area_footnotes = | rank = | length_mi = | length_footnotes = | width_mi = | width_footnotes = | coastline_mi = | coastline_footnotes = | elevation_ft = 3855 | elevation_footnotes = | highest_mount = | country = | demonym = | population = | population_as_of = | density_sqmi = | density_footnotes = | ethnic_groups = | website = | additional_info = }} '''Yorks Islands''', also known as "Yorks 8 Islands" or "York's Islands" or simply "York Island(s)" are a group of several islands in the flood plain of the [[Missouri River]], in [[Broadwater County]], [[Montana]], about 4 miles south (up-river) from [[Townsend, Montana]], along [[U.S. Highway 287]]. The islands were named by the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] (1803–1806) for Clark's servant/slave [[York (explorer)|York]], when the expedition passed this way in 1805 on their historic journey of exploration to the [[Pacific Ocean]]. The islands may be accessed from U.S.287, as a Montana Fishing Access site. ==Naming Yorks Islands== The islands were named for [[York (explorer)|York]] (ca. 1770-1831), Captain [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]]'s lifelong slave companion, and "body servant" who accompanied Clark on the expedition to the Pacific and back. The expedition passed this point on 24 July 1805. However, the naming of "Yorks 8 Islands" is not found in the narrative journals of [[Lewis and Clark]] for that day. Instead it is found in Clark’s tabulations on his map drawings, and in his list of “Creeks and Rivers,”. Clark's map for this area has the entry, “Yorks 8 Islands,” and under related remarks in Clark's "Creeks and Rivers" is “W.C. on land York tired.”[https://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/inside/york.html "York", part of PBS Site, "Inside the Corps"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507161617/http://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/inside/york.html |date=2015-05-07 }} PBS, "Inside the Corps", Article on "York" On Wednesday, July 24, 1805 Meriwether Lewis made the following entry in his journal, which describes his thoughts about the formation of Yorks Islands.
"we saw many beaver and some otter today; the former dam up the small channels of the river between the islands and compell the river in these parts to make other channels; which as soon as it has effected that which was stopped by the beaver becomes dry and is filled up with mud sand gravel and driftwood. the beaver is then compelled to seek another spot for his habitation wher[e] he again erects his dam. thus the river in many places among the clusters of islands is constantly changing the direction of such sluices as the beaver are capable of stoping or of 20 yds in width. this anamal in that way I believe to be very instrumental in adding to the number of islands with which we find the river crouded."{{cite web|url=http://www.onewest.net/~inmontana/crimsonbluffs/Yorks-Islands.htm |title=Yorks Island Fishing Access Commemorations |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507002936/http://www.onewest.net/~inmontana/crimsonbluffs/Yorks-Islands.htm |archivedate=May 7, 2011 }}
The captains followed the practice of naming geographic features after prominent persons who somehow had been connected with the expedition, particularly the President and members of his [[Presidential cabinet|cabinet]], (viz Jefferson, Madison, and [[Albert Gallatin|Gallatin]] Rivers) or attributes of President Jefferson (viz. Philanthropy, Philosophy, and Wisdom Rivers). In addition, as far as can be determined, a geographic feature was named for every Corps member, including [[Seaman]], Lewis’s Newfoundland dog.[https://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/inside/york.html "York", part of PBS Site, "Inside the Corps"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507161617/http://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/inside/york.html |date=2015-05-07 }} PBS, "Inside the Corps", Article on "York"] In 1806, on the return leg of the expedition down the Yellowstone River, Clark also named another geographical feature for York, "York's Dry Creek", a tributary of the Yellowstone River, in [[Custer County, Montana|Custer County]], [[Montana]].[http://travellogs.us/2007Logs/Montana%202007/131-Townsend/131dd-Yorks%20Islands.htm Yorks Islands from Lewis and Clark] This name did not stick and the creek became known as "Custer Creek". ==Official Recognition of nomenclature "Yorks Islands"== Though the name for "Yorks 8 Islands" appears on Clark's 1805 maps of the expeditions travel along the Missouri for July 24, 1805, the geographical designation for "Yorks Islands" was not officially confirmed until 2000, when the U.S. Board on Geographic Names[http://geonames.usgs.gov/ USGS, U.S. Board on Geographic Names] approved the name Yorks Islands for the group of Missouri River islands in Broadwater County.[http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=154:2:3589439785990734::NO:RP:: USGS Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) entry for "Yorks Islands"] The name was also approved by the Montana Board on Geographic Names and has been entered into the Nation’s official automated geographic names repository.[http://www.onewest.net/~inmontana/crimsonbluffs/Yorks-Islands.htm Yorks Islands Fishing Access Commemoration] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507002936/http://www.onewest.net/~inmontana/crimsonbluffs/Yorks-Islands.htm |date=May 7, 2011 }} The USGS ([[United States Geological Survey]]) [[Geographic Names Information System]] has settled on "Yorks Islands". However, the area is also called "York's Islands", or simply "York Island". ==Designation of "York's Islands Fishing Access Site"== The island group are now incorporated into "York's Islands Fishing Access Site", maintained by the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Department. This site is located on 22 acres along the east side of Missouri River 4 miles south of [[Townsend, Montana|Townsend]]. The site is just off of U.S. Highway 287. The site is marked by a Montana Fish and Wildlife Department sign. It includes a boat launch, picnic tables, fishing access, camping sites (including some for small trailers) and toilets. There is a small fee. There is no water or any other services.[http://goldwest.visitmt.com/listings/14022.htm York's Islands Fishing Access Site] ==Getting to Yorks Islands== Getting to Yorks Island: Utilize Google Earth for this area of Montana, or any map of the area, or simply drive 4 miles south of Townsend, Montana on [[U.S. Highway 287]], and look for the fishing access sign on the west side of the highway. ==See also== *[[York (explorer)]] *[[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] *[[William Clark (explorer)]] *[[Meriwether Lewis]] *[[Broadwater County, Montana]] *[[Missouri River]] *[[Custer Creek train wreck]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *York Island Fishing Access Commemoration [https://web.archive.org/web/20110507002936/http://www.onewest.net/~inmontana/crimsonbluffs/Yorks-Islands.htm] *Crimson Bluffs Chapter of the Lewis and Clark Trail Heritage Foundation [http://www.onewest.net/~inmontana/crimsonbluffs/whoweare.html] *York's Islands Fishin Access Site, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks [http://fwp.mt.gov/fishing/searchFas.html] *Lewis & Clark National Historic Interpretive Center, Great Falls, Montana] [http://www.lewisandclarktrail.com/section3/montanacities/greatfalls/lcinterpretive/index.htm] *National Geographic: Lewia & Clark [http://www.nationalgeographic.com/lewisandclark/] *Discovering Lewis & Clark [http://www.nationalgeographic.com/lewisandclark/] *Lewis & Clark - The Journey of the Corps of Discovery (PBS)[https://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/] *Lewis & Clark's Historic Trail [http://www.lewisclark.net/] *Lewis & Clark, Mapping the West (Smithsonian) [http://www.edgate.com/lewisandclark/] *Lewis & Clark and the Revealing of America(Library of Congress Exhibition)[https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/lewisandclark/lewisandclark.html] *Lewis & Clark 101 [http://www.lewisandclarktrail.com/101.htm] {{Broadwater County, Montana}} [[Category:River islands of Montana]] [[Category:Exploration of North America]] [[Category:Lewis and Clark Expedition]] [[Category:Landforms of Broadwater County, Montana]] [[Category:Islands of the Missouri River]] [[Category:Pre-statehood history of Montana]]
